docs.lead_paragraph: Rescue workers found at least five more people alive in the sea of mud in this ruined town today, including an 18-month-old boy. The development came after reports Sunday that the Government had suspended efforts to find survivors from the mudslides and flooding that struck Armero and 13 other villages and towns after the eruption Wednesday of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano. Today, army officers in Mariquita, not far from Armero, said they had been ordered to continue searching for 50 more hours. The army officers, who have been pessimistic from the start, said they had thought there was little chance of finding anyone else alive in the mud five days after it gushed over the town, propelled by flood waters that cascaded down the sides of the volcano. Had the Government carried out its plans to end the search and declare the whole town a cemetery, as the Minister of Health, Rafael de Zubiria, announced Sunday afternoon, these people would have been left to die.

headline.main: 5 MORE ARE FOUND ALIVE IN MUD AS COLOMBIAN SEARCH CONTINUES

docs.snippet: Rescue workers found at least five more people alive in the sea of mud in this ruined town today, including an 18-month-old boy.   The development came after reports Sunday that the Government had suspended efforts to find survivors from the...

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: CONSTITUTIONAL questions were the focus last week as lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union and Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford clashed in Superior Court here over the school's proposal to require student drug-screening tests. The proposal is believed to be the most inclusive of its kind in the nation. After almost two hours of argument on Tuesday, Judge Peter Ciolino said he expected to hand down a written opinion soon. The case, Odenheim et al. v. Carlstadt-East Rutherford Regional Board of Education, stems from a decision by the board last June to include tests for 12 types of drugs and alcohol as part of each student's annual physical examination.

headline.main: PLAN FOR STUDENT DRUG TESTS IN HANDS OF COURT

docs.snippet: CONSTITUTIONAL questions were the focus last week as lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union and Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford clashed in Superior Court here over the school's proposal to require student drug-screening tests. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency today approved the first deliberate release of genetically engineered organisms into the environment, a step that could inaugurate a revolution in using genetic technology for agricultural and environmental purposes. The agency's decision would allow Advanced Genetic Sciences, of Oakland, Calif., to conduct small-scale tests of two types of genetically altered bacteria designed to prevent frost damage to strawberry plants. Ordinarily, the plants are covered with millions of natural bacteria that promote the formation of ice crystals on exposed surfaces. The company plans to take some of these natural bacteria, remove the gene that causes the formation of ice, and then spray the altered bacteria on the strawberry plants so that they will crowd out the ice-forming bacteria and protect the plants from damage.

headline.main: FIELD TEST OF GENE-ALTERED BACTERIA IS APPROVED
